input: sentence 1: The foxes are getting in at night and attacking the chickens. They have gotten very bold. [SEP] sentence 2: The chickens have gotten very bold.
sentence 1: I was trying to open the lock with the key, but someone had filled the keyhole with chewing gum, and I couldn't get it in. [SEP] sentence 2: I couldn't get the chewing gum in.
sentence 1: Since Chester was dependent on Uncle Vernon, he couldn't very well marry without his approval [SEP] sentence 2: Chester couldn't very well marry without his approval
sentence 1: I stuck a pin through a carrot. When I pulled the pin out, it had a hole. [SEP] sentence 2: The pin had a hole.

sentence 1: A number of times Henry had been present at interviews which his father had had with noted detectives who desired his aid in solving perplexing mysteries, and those occasions stood out as red-letter days for him. [SEP] sentence 2: Those occasions stood out as red-letter days for father.

sentence 1: Mark was close to Mr. Singer's heels. He heard him calling for the captain, promising him, in the jargon everyone talked that night, that not one thing should be damaged on the ship except only the ammunition, but the captain and all his crew had best stay in the cabin until the work was over. [SEP] sentence 2: The captain and all Mark's crew had best stay in the cabin until the work was over.

sentence 1: All the buttons up the back of Dora's plaid dress were buttoned outside-in. Maude should have thought to button her up; but no, she had left poor little Dora to do the best she could, alone. [SEP] sentence 2: She had left poor little Dora to do the best Dora could, alone.
sentence 1: Steve follows Fred's example in everything. He admires him hugely. [SEP] sentence 2: Steve admires him hugely.
sentence 1: Even before they reached town, they could hear a sound like corn popping. Dora asked what it was, and Dad said it was firecrackers. [SEP] sentence 2: Dora asked what the town was.

sentence 1: The table was piled high with food, and on the floor beside it there were crocks, baskets, and a five-quart pail of milk. [SEP] sentence 2: Beside the floor there were crocks, baskets, and a five-quart pail of milk.

sentence 1: Alice was dusting the living room and trying to find the button that Mama had hidden. No time today to look at old pictures in her favorite photo album. Today she had to hunt for a button, so she put the album on a chair without even opening it. [SEP] sentence 2: Alice had to hunt for a button.
sentence 1: Susan knew that Ann's son had been in a car accident, because she told her about it. [SEP] sentence 2: Ann told her about it.
sentence 1: Jackson was greatly influenced by Arnold, though he lived two centuries earlier. [SEP] sentence 2: Arnold lived two centuries earlier.
sentence 1: Bob collapsed on the sidewalk. Soon he saw Carl coming to help. He was very ill. [SEP] sentence 2: Bob was very ill.

sentence 1: Sara borrowed the book from the library because she needs it for an article she is working on. She reads it when she gets home from work. [SEP] sentence 2: She reads the article when she gets home from work.

sentence 1: Mark became absorbed in Blaze, the white horse. He was afraid the stable boys at the Burlington Stables struck at him and bullied him because he was timid, so he took upon himself the feeding and care of the animal. [SEP] sentence 2: Blaze was afraid the stable boys at the Burlington Stables struck at him and bullied him.
